{{Infobox Election | election_name = Italian general election, 2008 | country = Italy | type = legislative | ongoing = no | previous_election = Italian general election, 2006 | previous_year = 2006 | next_election = Italian general election, 2013 | next_year = Next | seats_for_election = All 630 seats to the [[Italian Chamber of Deputies]]
316 seats were needed for a majority in the Chamber

43.0%, total 49.7% | seats1 = 344 (H)
174 (S) | seat_change1 = {{increase}} 141 | popular_vote1 = 17,063,874 | percentage1 = 46.8% | swing1 = {{increase}} 3.8% | image2 = [[File:Walter Veltroni 3 cropped.jpg|125px]] | leader2 = [[Walter Veltroni]] | party2 = Democratic Party (Italy) | alliance2 = Walter Veltroni | leader_since2 = October 14, 2007 | leaders_seat2 = XV - [[Province of Rome|Rome]] | last_election2 = 243 & 113 seats,
33.5%, total 49.8% | seats2 = 246 (H)
134 (S) | seat_change2 = {{increase}} 24 | popular_vote2 = 13,686,673 | percentage2 = 37.5% | swing2 = {{increase}} 4.0% | title = [[Prime Minister of Italy|Prime Minister]] | posttitle = [[Prime Minister of Italy|Prime Minister]] | before_election = [[Romano Prodi]] | before_party = Democratic Party (Italy) | after_election = [[Silvio Berlusconi]] | after_party = People of Freedom }} A [[Snap election|snap]] '''general election''' was held in [[Italy]] on 13 April and 14 April 2008.{{cite news|publisher=Bloomberg.com|title=Italy's President Dissolves Parliament, Forces Vote|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601085&sid=aZqWocwYgLxo&refer=europe|accessdate=2008-02-08|date=2008-02-06}} The election came after [[President of the Italian Republic|President]] [[Giorgio Napolitano]] dissolved [[Parliament of Italy|parliament]] on 6 February 2008 following the [[2008 Italian political crisis|defeat of the government]] of [[President of the Council of Ministers of Italy|Prime Minister]] [[Romano Prodi]] in a January 2008 [[Italian Senate|Senate]] vote,{{cite news|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=2008-02-06|date=2008-02-06|title=Italy to hold snap April election|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/7230275.stm}} and the unsuccessful tentative appointment of [[Franco Marini]] with the aim to change the current electoral law. Under Italian law, elections must be held within 70 days of the dissolution. The voting determined the leader of Italy's 62nd[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/7348448.stm Berlusconi plans Naples clean-up] BBC News, 15 April 2008 government since the end of [[World War II]]. The coalition led by ex-Prime Minister [[Silvio Berlusconi]] from the [[People of Freedom]] party defeated that of former [[Rome]] Mayor [[Walter Veltroni]] of the [[Democratic Party (Italy)|Democratic Party]].[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/7347618.stm Berlusconi declares election win] BBC News, 14 April 2008 ==Electoral system== Italians voted in this election with [[Parliament of Italy#Electoral System|the same electoral system]] used in [[Italian general election, 2006|2006]], based on [[party-list]] representation. This electoral systems allow parties to formally define coalitions. The coalition with a [[Plurality (voting)|plurality]] of votes nationwide then obtains an absolute majority of seats in the Chamber of Deputies. This is not in Senate's case, as absolute majorities of seats are awarded regionally.{{or|date=November 2011}} {{Politics of Italy}} ==Parties== Major competitors in the election were expected to be [[Silvio Berlusconi]], as leader of the centre-right opposition coalition, and [[Walter Veltroni]], leader of the [[Democratic Party (Italy)|Democratic Party]]. Berlusconi's right coalition was leading by a significant margin in opinion polls.{{cite news|publisher=The New York Times|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/07/world/europe/07italy.html|title=With Flawed System Unchanged, Italy Sets Elections for April|date=2008-02-07|accessdate=2008-02-08|author=Elisabeth Rosenthal}} The 71-year-old Berlusconi, who was twice prime minister—from May 1994 to January 1995 and again from May 2001 to May 2006—is not considered too old for the job although he had heart surgery since leaving office.{{cite news|publisher=cnn.com|title=Italy faces second day of voting|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/europe/04/14/italy.election/index.html|accessdate=2008-04-14|date=2008-04-14 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080415105238/http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/europe/04/14/italy.election/index.html |archivedate = 2008-04-15}} Veltroni's campaign has been compared to [[Barack Obama presidential campaign, 2008|Barack Obama's presidential run]] in the [[United States]]. The most apparent of the similarities is his slogan, "Si puÃ² fare" (literally: "it can be done"). Following the calling of the election, Veltroni stated his party will not make any alliance in either Chamber, choosing instead to run alone with its own platform, and challenged Berlusconi to do likewise with his [[Forza Italia]] party. The main four left-wing parties not part of the PD decided to contest the election together under the banner of [[The Left â The Rainbow]]. On February 8, Berlusconi announced [[Forza Italia]] and [[Gianfranco Fini]]'s [[National Alliance (Italy)|National Alliance]] will run together under the common symbol of the [[People of Freedom]] party, being regionally allied with [[Lega Nord]].{{cite news|url=http://www.corriere.it/politica/08_febbraio_08/an_fi_2c7def76-d618-11dc-88e3-0003ba99c667.shtml|publisher=Corriere della Sera|language=Italian|title=Berlusconi: Â«Simbolo unico per Fi e AnÂ»|date=2008-02-08|accessdate=2008-02-08}} On February 13, Veltroni announced to have reached an agreement with the [[Italy of Values]], led by [[Antonio Di Pietro]], which agreed for an electoral alliance with the Democratic Party, accepting also to join the Democratic Party parliamentary groups after the election.{{cite news|url=http://www.ansa.it/site/notizie/awnplus/italia/news/2008-02-13_113191367.html|publisher=ANSA.it|title=Pd: accordo Di Pietro- Veltroni|date=2008-02-13|accessdate=2008-02-21|language=Italian}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} On February 21 the [[Italian Radicals]] announced an agreement with the Democratic Party, accepting to present themselves in list with the latter, under the agreement they will have nine MPs elected in the Parliament, and appointment of [[Emma Bonino]] as Minister in case of victory.{{cite news|url=http://www.unita.it/view.asp?IDcontent=73109|publisher=L'UnitÃ |title=I Radicali dicono sÃ¬ al Pd: 9 seggi e Bonino ministro|date=2008-02-21|accessdate=2008-02-21|language=Italian}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Though Berlusconi and Veltroni were in opposite parties, they allegedly represent such similar policies that they were dubbed "Veltrusconi". Both candidates supported big [[tax cut]]s and generous spending programs. [[Union of Christian and Centre Democrats]] was invited to support Berlusconi, but refused and decided to run on its own instead. [[White Rose (Italy)|White Rose]] originally planned to run alone with [[Bruno Tabacci]] as their PM candidate, but shortly before the filing deadline, they decided to form joint lists with the UDC.{{fact|date=November 2011}} ==Result== ===Chamber of Deputies ("Camera dei Deputati") (Lower house)=== {{electiontable|Italian general election, 2008-Deputies}}'''Summary of the 13–14 April 2008 [[Chamber of Deputies of Italy]] [[Italian general election, 2008|election results]]''' |- |- bgcolor="#E9E9E9" !Candidates !Votes !% !Seats !Parties inside coalitions !Votes !% !Seats |- !rowspan="4" valign="top"|[[Silvio Berlusconi]] |rowspan="4" valign="top"|17,064,314 |rowspan="4" valign="top"|46.811 |rowspan="4" valign="top"|'''344''' |rowspan="2" align="left" valign="top"|{{lang|it|[[People of Freedom]]}} |valign="top"|13,629,069 |valign="top"|37.388 |valign="top"|272 |- |- | | |abroad: 4 |- |align="left"|[[Lega Nord]] |3,024,758 |8.297 |60 |- |align="left"|[[Movement for Autonomy]] |410,487 |1.126 |4 |- !rowspan="4" valign="top"|[[Walter Veltroni]] |rowspan="4" valign="top"|13,686,501 |rowspan="4" valign="top"|37.546 |rowspan="4" valign="top"|'''246''' |rowspan="2" align="left" valign="top"|{{lang|it|[[Democratic Party (Italy)|Democratic Party]]}} |12,092,969 |33.174 |211 |- | | |abroad: 6 |- |rowspan="2" align="left" valign="top"|{{lang|it|[[Italy of Values]]}} |1,593,532 |4.371 |28 |- | | |abroad: 1 |- !rowspan="1" valign="top"|[[Pier Ferdinando Casini]] |rowspan="1" valign="top"|2,050,229 |rowspan="1" valign="top"|5.624 |rowspan="1" valign="top"|'''36''' |align="left"|[[Union of the Centre (2008)|Union of the Centre]] |2,050,229 |5.624 |36 |- !rowspan="1" valign="top"|[[Fausto Bertinotti]] |rowspan="1" valign="top"|1,124,298 |rowspan="1" valign="top"|3.084 |rowspan="1" valign="top"| -
